results.title: TV50 Celebrity Interviews
results.creator_credit: Astrid Scott, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description: Interviews with thirteen celebrities from Australian television. Asked the same questions, their responses are recorded vox pop style. Questions asked concern the celebrities’ experiences of television both as a viewer and as a personality and performer as well as their thoughts on reality television and the state of Australian television in general. Interviews were conducted at ACMI for the TV50 exhibition in 2006.

results.title: Mary and Max: The Exhibition: interview with Adam Elliot March 2010
results.brief_description: Oscar winning animation director and writer Adam Elliot speaks candidly about his stop frame animation processes and, more importantly, about why he makes films. Adam also talks about the challenges he faced during the making of his first feature film ‘Mary and Max’.

results.title: An Interview with Gillian Armstrong
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Award-winning Australian film and documentary director Gillian Armstrong’s film career spans over 40 years locally and internationally.

Here she shares her discovery of Orry-Kelly and the incredibly fortunate set of events that uncovered his memoir and his box of memorabilia including his three Oscars.

The release of Armstrong’s 2015 feature-length documentary on the life and work of renowned costume designer Orry-Kelly, ‘Women He’s Undressed’, coincided with ACMI’s exhibition ‘Orry-Kelly: Dressing Hollywood’.

results.title: Tusalava
results.brief_description: 1. Lye’s first film was originally accompanied by live music by Jack Ellit. No score was ever found, so the film presented here is silent, a vision of the beginnings of life on earth - mixing Maori, silent and modernist influences.

results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton
results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.
results.title_for_label: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.title: Neal Benezra 21st Century Museums: SFMOMA Looking Forward
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Neal Benezra, director of San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SFMOMA), talks about the history of the institution with regards to its upcoming expansion. Benezra tells the story of his journey to find the architects who designed the expansion and explains the thinking behind the vision for the building.

This talk featured as part of the ‘William Kentridge: Five Themes’ exhibition public programs events. The exhibition was originally curated by SFMOMA in 2009 and has since travelled to New York, Paris, Vienna, Jerusalem and Moscow.

results.title: [District Nursing Appeal]
results.brief_description:
The Royal District Nursing Service was founded in 1885 and was originally called the Melbourne District Nursing Service. An initiative led by the Reverend Charles Strong, the organisation was established to nurse the sick, poor and disadvantaged in their own homes. By the early 1920s the nurses were treating 25,000 patients per year and had established a convalescent institution, the After-Care Home (later Hospital) in Collingwood. In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.

In 1966 the organisation became the Royal District Nursing Service.

In this television appeal from 1967, Graham Kennedy presents a feature on behalf of the Royal District Nursing Service. The film includes footage of Kennedy in the television studio, appealing for door knockers to help fundraise for the organisation. The program shows footage of Kennedy interviewing an elderly war veteran at his home in Albert Park, who lives alone and is visited by an RDNS nurse every day.

It appears this film was produced as a Kinescope - a 16mm film recording of a live television broadcast. As such, both the sound and image are a little ‘muddy’ as is typical of this technology.
